text: This parameter is increased five- to seven-fold in a device that produces a solid angle approaching 4 pi. The central zero generated by a doughnut-shaped beam enhances this quantity in stimulated emission depletion. It is significantly increased axially in interferometric PALM, which utilizes the SML principle of photoswitchable fluorophores. The highest value for this quantity can be approximated with the FWHM of a point spread function. It can be calculated as 1.22 times lambda over the radius of the Airy disk according to the Rayleigh (RAY-lee) criterion, or lambda over two times the numerical aperture as quantified by Ernst Abbe (AH-buh). For 10 points, name this parameter restricted by the diffraction limit to around 200 nanometers, which represents the minimum distance at which two points can be distinguished.
answer: resolution [or resolving power; or angular resolution; or spatial resolution; prompt on diffraction limit until it is read; prompt on things like image sharpness; prompt on power] <The above question is for the category Science Physics and was written by Joelle Smart> 2018 National All-Star Academic Tournament Round 20 – Bonuses
formatted_text: This parameter is increased five- to seven-fold in a device that produces a solid angle approaching 4 pi. The central zero generated by a doughnut-shaped beam enhances this quantity in stimulated emission depletion. It is significantly increased axially in interferometric PALM, which utilizes the SML principle of photoswitchable fluorophores. The highest value for this quantity can be approximated with the FWHM of a point spread function. It can be calculated as 1.22 times lambda over the radius of the Airy disk according to the Rayleigh (RAY-lee) criterion, or lambda over two times the numerical aperture as quantified by Ernst Abbe (AH-buh). text: Chilean local traditions tell of a ghostly one of these objects known as the Caleuche (kah-lay-OO-chay). A self-operating one of these objects known as “Scuabtuinne” (scoob-tin-uh) is owned by Manannán mac Lir (MAH-nah-nahn mac LEER). One of these objects is owned by Freyja (FRAY-uh) and, like her hall, has the name Sessrúmnir. Utnapishtim (OOT-na-PISH-tim) creates a giant one of these objects called “The Preserver of Life.” A competition involving two stone examples of these objects was won when one of them was actually constructed of wood painted to resemble stone; that competition involving these objects led to Horus being crowned the ruler of Egypt instead of Set. Ra rides on, for 10 points, what type of vehicle that transports the sun in Egyptian mythology?
answer: boats [or ships; or other synonyms] <The above question is for the category RMP Non-Greek/Roman Myth and was written by Conor Thompson>
formatted_text: Chilean local traditions tell of a ghostly one of these objects known as the Caleuche (kah-lay-OO-chay). A self-operating one of these objects known as “Scuabtuinne” (scoob-tin-uh) is owned by Manannán mac Lir (MAH-nah-nahn mac LEER). One of these objects is owned by Freyja (FRAY-uh) and, like her hall, has the name Sessrúmnir. Utnapishtim (OOT-na-PISH-tim) creates a giant one of these objects called “The Preserver of Life.” A competition involving two stone examples of these objects was won when one of them was actually constructed of wood painted to resemble stone; that competition involving these objects led to Horus being crowned the ruler of Egypt instead of Set. Ra rides on, for 10 points, what type of vehicle that transports the sun in Egyptian mythology?
formatted_answer: boats [or ships; or other synonyms] <The above question is for the category RMP Non-Greek/Roman Myth and was written by Conor Thompson>

text: This person hired an indigenous woman named Tarita to play his love interest, rewrote a script to move the title shipboard event to a flashback, and effectively took over directing himself from Carol Reed in a troubled film in which he portrayed Fletcher Christian. A character played by this man confesses to Edie, while his words are drowned out by the sound of a ship’s whistle and machinery. While playing a motorcycle gang member, this actor asked “whaddya got?” after being asked what he was rebelling against. In another film, this star of The Wild One played the brother of Charley “the Gent,” who works for gangster Johnny Friendly. In that film, this actor’s character of Terry Malloy is a former boxer who laments that he “coulda been a contender.” For 10 points, name this actor who won an Oscar for On the Waterfront and shouted “Stella!” in the film version of A Streetcar Named Desire.
answer: Marlon Brando Jr. <The above question is for the category Arts Film and was written by Mike Cheyne>
formatted_text: This person hired an indigenous woman named Tarita to play his love interest, rewrote a script to move the title shipboard event to a flashback, and effectively took over directing himself from Carol Reed in a troubled film in which he portrayed Fletcher Christian. A character played by this man confesses to Edie, while his words are drowned out by the sound of a ship’s whistle and machinery. While playing a motorcycle gang member, this actor asked “whaddya got?” after being asked what he was rebelling against. In another film, this star of The Wild One played the brother of Charley “the Gent,” who works for gangster Johnny Friendly. In that film, this actor’s character of Terry Malloy is a former boxer who laments that he “coulda been a contender.” For 10 points, name this actor who won an Oscar for On the Waterfront and shouted “Stella!” in the film version of A Streetcar Named Desire.
formatted_answer: Marlon Brando Jr. <The above question is for the category Arts Film and was written by Mike Cheyne>

text: Anselmus is cursed by a woman who sells these things after he knocks down her wares in the E. T. A. Hoffman story “The Golden Pot.” A Rainer Maria Rilke (RILL-kuh) poem mourns how we will never know the eyes of a headless archaic torso, which are compared to these things. In another story, a woman runs in in her underclothes to stop a man who filled his pockets from throwing these things at his son. A rotting one of these things is surrounded by “white dust” after it has lodged itself in Gregor Samsa’s abdomen. For 10 points, in Schiller’s William Tell, Walter makes sure to remain as still as possible while his father shoots what fruit off of his head?
answer: apples [or Augenäpfel; or apfel] <The above question is for the category Literature European and was written by Daoud Jackson>
formatted_text: Anselmus is cursed by a woman who sells these things after he knocks down her wares in the E. T. A. Hoffman story “The Golden Pot.” A Rainer Maria Rilke (RILL-kuh) poem mourns how we will never know the eyes of a headless archaic torso, which are compared to these things. In another story, a woman runs in in her underclothes to stop a man who filled his pockets from throwing these things at his son. A rotting one of these things is surrounded by “white dust” after it has lodged itself in Gregor Samsa’s abdomen. For 10 points, in Schiller’s William Tell, Walter makes sure to remain as still as possible while his father shoots what fruit off of his head?
formatted_answer: apples [or Augenäpfel; or apfel] <The above question is for the category Literature European and was written by Daoud Jackson>

text: This group’s rise supplanted similar forces led by Tinker Fox. Christopher Hill argued that William Erbery was able to describe this force as “the Army of God” with a theology centred on Adam. Robert Lockyer, a member of this force, was executed for his role in the Bishopsgate Mutiny while serving in the regiment of Edward Whalley. “Agitators” in this group argued with “Grandees” such as Henry Ireton at the Putney Debates. The earls of Essex and Manchester were unable to serve in this force as a result of the Self-Denying Ordinance. This force commanded by Thomas Fairfax was victorious at the battles of Naseby and Marston Moor. For 10 points, name this army which fought for Parliament during the English Civil War.
answer: New Model Army <The above question is for the category History European 1400-1914 and was written by Daoud Jackson>
formatted_text: This group’s rise supplanted similar forces led by Tinker Fox. Christopher Hill argued that William Erbery was able to describe this force as “the Army of God” with a theology centred on Adam. Robert Lockyer, a member of this force, was executed for his role in the Bishopsgate Mutiny while serving in the regiment of Edward Whalley. “Agitators” in this group argued with “Grandees” such as Henry Ireton at the Putney Debates. The earls of Essex and Manchester were unable to serve in this force as a result of the Self-Denying Ordinance. This force commanded by Thomas Fairfax was victorious at the battles of Naseby and Marston Moor. For 10 points, name this army which fought for Parliament during the English Civil War.
formatted_answer: New Model Army <The above question is for the category History European 1400-1914 and was written by Daoud Jackson>

text: A poem by James D. Corrother describes a competition with this man while they “wiz a-hoein’ in de co’n.” In a patriotic poem, this writer praises “those noble sons of Ham” “who fought for Uncle Sam!” This writer took out a loan to publish his first collection Oak and Ivy whose shorter second section is composed of dialect poems. Some critics have argued that this author expressed frustration with his white patrons in a poem describing how “with torn and bleeding hearts we smile.” This poet described a motive in one of his poems as “a plea, that upward to Heaven he flings–” and a line from that poem, Sympathy was used as the title of Maya Angelou’s I Know Why The Caged Bird Sings. For 10 points, name this African-American poet of “We Wear the Mask.”
answer: Paul Laurence Dunbar <The above question is for the category Literature American and was written by Daoud Jackson>
formatted_text: A poem by James D. Corrother describes a competition with this man while they “wiz a-hoein’ in de co’n.” In a patriotic poem, this writer praises “those noble sons of Ham” “who fought for Uncle Sam!” This writer took out a loan to publish his first collection Oak and Ivy whose shorter second section is composed of dialect poems. Some critics have argued that this author expressed frustration with his white patrons in a poem describing how “with torn and bleeding hearts we smile.” This poet described a motive in one of his poems as “a plea, that upward to Heaven he flings–” and a line from that poem, Sympathy was used as the title of Maya Angelou’s I Know Why The Caged Bird Sings. For 10 points, name this African-American poet of “We Wear the Mask.”
formatted_answer: Paul Laurence Dunbar <The above question is for the category Literature American and was written by Daoud Jackson>

text: A thought experiment in this book imagines a sequence of nine cases from brutal slavery to apparently free elections, asking what point one is no longer a slave. A footnote in this book asks whether utilitarian goal-centered views can be reconciled with the author’s view of rights as side-constraints on action. This book formulates a Lockean proviso to determine when property acquisition is just, and it imagines one million people freely choosing to give money to Wilt Chamberlain in order to argue against another philosopher’s difference principle. This book advocates a minimal night-watchman state and was written in response to John Rawls’s A Theory of Justice. For 10 points, name this book of libertarian political philosophy by Robert Nozick.
answer: Anarchy, State and Utopia <The above question is for the category RMP Philosophy and was written by Shan Kothari>
formatted_text: A thought experiment in this book imagines a sequence of nine cases from brutal slavery to apparently free elections, asking what point one is no longer a slave. A footnote in this book asks whether utilitarian goal-centered views can be reconciled with the author’s view of rights as side-constraints on action. This book formulates a Lockean proviso to determine when property acquisition is just, and it imagines one million people freely choosing to give money to Wilt Chamberlain in order to argue against another philosopher’s difference principle. This book advocates a minimal night-watchman state and was written in response to John Rawls’s A Theory of Justice. For 10 points, name this book of libertarian political philosophy by Robert Nozick.
formatted_answer: Anarchy, State and Utopia <The above question is for the category RMP Philosophy and was written by Shan Kothari>

text: The path integral formulation for these particles involve using Grassmann numbers. The Gross–Neveu and Nambu–Jona–Lasinio theories model the interaction of four of these particles. Deborah Jin used potassium-40 atoms cooled to 5 times 10-to-the-negative-8th kelvins to produce these particles’ namesake condensate. Observing neutrinoless double beta decay would prove the existence of one type of these particles as opposed to ones named for Dirac. Simple multi-particle wavefunctions for these particles can be represented by a Slater determinant. These particles can be coupled at low temperatures to form Cooper pairs, and they cannot have same quantum numbers according to Pauli exclusion principle. For 10 points, name these particles that possess half-integer spins.
answer: fermions [or fermionic fields; prompt on neutrinos; prompt on electrons] <The above question is for the category Science Physics and was written by Paul Lee>
formatted_text: The path integral formulation for these particles involve using Grassmann numbers. The Gross–Neveu and Nambu–Jona–Lasinio theories model the interaction of four of these particles. Deborah Jin used potassium-40 atoms cooled to 5 times 10-to-the-negative-8th kelvins to produce these particles’ namesake condensate. Observing neutrinoless double beta decay would prove the existence of one type of these particles as opposed to ones named for Dirac. Simple multi-particle wavefunctions for these particles can be represented by a Slater determinant. These particles can be coupled at low temperatures to form Cooper pairs, and they cannot have same quantum numbers according to Pauli exclusion principle. For 10 points, name these particles that possess half-integer spins.
formatted_answer: fermions [or fermionic fields; prompt on neutrinos; prompt on electrons] <The above question is for the category Science Physics and was written by Paul Lee>

text: Michael Baxandall argued that barrel-gauging and other forms of commercial mathematics influenced this painter’s use of geometric forms. A thesis that one of this man’s paintings depicts Bessarion trying to convince Federico of Urbino to launch a crusade was supported by Carlo Ginzburg. A fresco by this man, which Aldous Huxley described as “the best picture in the world,” depicts four sleeping guards in front of Jesus, who raises a flag and lifts his foot onto a sarcophagus. Besides that version of The Resurrection, he painted a scene with three men in a courtyard on the right, one in a blue-and-gold robe, as Christ is tied to a pillar topped by a gold statue and whipped. For 10 points, name this early Renaissance painter of The Flagellation of Christ.
answer: Piero della Francesca [or della Francesca] <The above question is for the category Arts Painting and was written by Shan Kothari>
formatted_text: Michael Baxandall argued that barrel-gauging and other forms of commercial mathematics influenced this painter’s use of geometric forms. A thesis that one of this man’s paintings depicts Bessarion trying to convince Federico of Urbino to launch a crusade was supported by Carlo Ginzburg. A fresco by this man, which Aldous Huxley described as “the best picture in the world,” depicts four sleeping guards in front of Jesus, who raises a flag and lifts his foot onto a sarcophagus. Besides that version of The Resurrection, he painted a scene with three men in a courtyard on the right, one in a blue-and-gold robe, as Christ is tied to a pillar topped by a gold statue and whipped. For 10 points, name this early Renaissance painter of The Flagellation of Christ.
formatted_answer: Piero della Francesca [or della Francesca] <The above question is for the category Arts Painting and was written by Shan Kothari>

text: During this election, New York’s William P. Van Ness sent a secret letter to Edward Livingston, detailing an ultimately failed plan to defeat the winning candidate. This election was the subject of the pamphlet “The Prospect Before Us” by James Callender, who was eventually pardoned by the winner. The losing candidate in this election was condemned for his “reign of terror” by the newspaper Aurora, and his own party sought to dump him for his running mate, Charles C. Pinckney. This election led to the passage of the 12th Amendment after a tie occurred between the men on the winning “ticket.” For 10 points, name this first presidential election in which power was transferred between parties, in which Thomas Jefferson defeated John Adams.
answer: Election of 1800 [or Revolution of 1800] <The above question is for the category History American (pre-1865) and was written by Mike Cheyne>
formatted_text: During this election, New York’s William P. Van Ness sent a secret letter to Edward Livingston, detailing an ultimately failed plan to defeat the winning candidate. This election was the subject of the pamphlet “The Prospect Before Us” by James Callender, who was eventually pardoned by the winner. The losing candidate in this election was condemned for his “reign of terror” by the newspaper Aurora, and his own party sought to dump him for his running mate, Charles C. Pinckney. This election led to the passage of the 12th Amendment after a tie occurred between the men on the winning “ticket.” For 10 points, name this first presidential election in which power was transferred between parties, in which Thomas Jefferson defeated John Adams.
formatted_answer: Election of 1800 [or Revolution of 1800] <The above question is for the category History American (pre-1865) and was written by Mike Cheyne>

text: A thought experiment considering members of Congress is used to criticize these procedures in Jacob Cohen’s essay “The Earth is Round.” Sture Holm co-names a method used to counteract error rates in some types of this procedure. In these procedures, the Bonferroni correction may be employed to render the results more accurate. The “generalized” form of this procedure typically involves considering the distribution of 2 times the log of capital lambda. The superiority of a particular type of this procedure is established by the Neyman–Pearson lemma. The size of one of these procedures is typically denoted by alpha, and the calculation of a statistic in the critical region leads to the rejection of H-nought in these procedures. For 10 points, name this type of procedure in which “null” and “alternative” models are contrasted to determine if data is statistically significant.
answer: hypothesis tests [or word forms; or significance tests; prompt on tests; prompt on statistical tests; prompt on multiple testing] <The above question is for the category Science Math and was written by Joseph Krol>
formatted_text: A thought experiment considering members of Congress is used to criticize these procedures in Jacob Cohen’s essay “The Earth is Round.” Sture Holm co-names a method used to counteract error rates in some types of this procedure. In these procedures, the Bonferroni correction may be employed to render the results more accurate. The “generalized” form of this procedure typically involves considering the distribution of 2 times the log of capital lambda. The superiority of a particular type of this procedure is established by the Neyman–Pearson lemma. The size of one of these procedures is typically denoted by alpha, and the calculation of a statistic in the critical region leads to the rejection of H-nought in these procedures. For 10 points, name this type of procedure in which “null” and “alternative” models are contrasted to determine if data is statistically significant.
formatted_answer: hypothesis tests [or word forms; or significance tests; prompt on tests; prompt on statistical tests; prompt on multiple testing] <The above question is for the category Science Math and was written by Joseph Krol>

text: An artist from this country wrote the wordless song “September,” sometimes called this country’s “wedding song,” on an album whose title translates to “New Time”; that artist from this country is Ivan Lins (ee-VAHN LEENSS). A friction drum from this country that makes a high-pitched squeaking sound is the cuíca (koo-EE-ka). A black and a mixed-race child sit on a roadside on the cover of an iconic album from this country whose name means “the corner club”; that album is by Milton Nascimento (MEEL-tone nah-see-MAIN-too) and Lô Borges (BOR-zhiss). For 10 points, name this country whose popular music incorporated the developments made by Antônio Carlos Jobim (jo-BEEM), João Gilberto (zh’WOW jeel-BAIR-too), and other Bossa Nova artists.
answer: Brazil [Federative Republic of Brazil; or República Federativa do Brasil] [The first clue refers to “Setembro” and Novo Tempo; the third clue refers to Clube da Esquina.] <The above question is for the category Arts Music and was written by John Marvin>
formatted_text: An artist from this country wrote the wordless song “September,” sometimes called this country’s “wedding song,” on an album whose title translates to “New Time”; that artist from this country is Ivan Lins (ee-VAHN LEENSS). A friction drum from this country that makes a high-pitched squeaking sound is the cuíca (koo-EE-ka). A black and a mixed-race child sit on a roadside on the cover of an iconic album from this country whose name means “the corner club”; that album is by Milton Nascimento (MEEL-tone nah-see-MAIN-too) and Lô Borges (BOR-zhiss). For 10 points, name this country whose popular music incorporated the developments made by Antônio Carlos Jobim (jo-BEEM), João Gilberto (zh’WOW jeel-BAIR-too), and other Bossa Nova artists.
formatted_answer: Brazil [Federative Republic of Brazil; or República Federativa do Brasil] [The first clue refers to “Setembro” and Novo Tempo; the third clue refers to Clube da Esquina.] <The above question is for the category Arts Music and was written by John Marvin>

text: The second king of this name expelled the usurper Zaviš of Falkenstein and conquered Kraków to claim an additional throne. The fourth king of this name ordered the murder of John of Nepomuk during a struggle with archbishop Jan of Jenštejn (YAHN of YEN-stein). The first king of this name was raised by his grandmother, a martyr who was strangled at Tetin Castle by forces of the pagan regent, his mother Drahomíra. This name was borne by the protégé of Saint Ludmila who was killed after refusing to fight Henry the Fowler. The first king of this name was succeeded by his younger brother, Boleslav the Cruel, who continued his Přemyslid (puh-SEM-iss-lid) dynasty. For 10 points, give this name of four kings of Bohemia, the first of whom “looked out on the feast of Stephen” in a Christmas carol about him being a “Good king.”
answer: Wenceslas <The above question is for the category History European to 1400 and was written by Penelope Ashe>
formatted_text: The second king of this name expelled the usurper Zaviš of Falkenstein and conquered Kraków to claim an additional throne. The fourth king of this name ordered the murder of John of Nepomuk during a struggle with archbishop Jan of Jenštejn (YAHN of YEN-stein). The first king of this name was raised by his grandmother, a martyr who was strangled at Tetin Castle by forces of the pagan regent, his mother Drahomíra. This name was borne by the protégé of Saint Ludmila who was killed after refusing to fight Henry the Fowler. The first king of this name was succeeded by his younger brother, Boleslav the Cruel, who continued his Přemyslid (puh-SEM-iss-lid) dynasty. For 10 points, give this name of four kings of Bohemia, the first of whom “looked out on the feast of Stephen” in a Christmas carol about him being a “Good king.”
formatted_answer: Wenceslas <The above question is for the category History European to 1400 and was written by Penelope Ashe>

text: A woman called Meme (may-may) inquires of a man with this title after that ageing father buries a reclusive doctor. A character with this title is nearly swindled out of his dead son’s prize cockerel by Sabato; in that novel, partly titled for someone of this rank, that character visits the same office weekly for fifteen years, futilely hoping to receive a pension. The protagonist of Leaf Storm holds this rank, as does a character who dies by the same chestnut tree to which his mad father was tied. That character with this rank “remembers that distant afternoon when his father took him to discover ice” at the start of One Hundred Years of Solitude. For 10 points, “no one writes to” a person of what military rank, also held by Aureliano Buendia?
answer: colonel <The above question is for the category Literature World and was written by Joseph Krol>
formatted_text: A woman called Meme (may-may) inquires of a man with this title after that ageing father buries a reclusive doctor. A character with this title is nearly swindled out of his dead son’s prize cockerel by Sabato; in that novel, partly titled for someone of this rank, that character visits the same office weekly for fifteen years, futilely hoping to receive a pension. The protagonist of Leaf Storm holds this rank, as does a character who dies by the same chestnut tree to which his mad father was tied. That character with this rank “remembers that distant afternoon when his father took him to discover ice” at the start of One Hundred Years of Solitude. For 10 points, “no one writes to” a person of what military rank, also held by Aureliano Buendia?
formatted_answer: colonel <The above question is for the category Literature World and was written by Joseph Krol>

text: In 2013, Zhang (jong) et al. produced versions of this compound with differing stoichiometric ratios using high-pressure diamond anvil cells. This compound is produced as a side product in addition to ammonia in the Olin–Raschig process for industrial production of hydrazine. This is the lighter of the two compounds commonly used to make sample plates for IR spectroscopy. It is not a phosphate compound, but this is the compound present in highest concentration in a solution commonly used to wash cells prior to dissociation. A solution containing this compound is used to remove any aqueous workup from the organic layer during liquid-liquid extraction. This cubic crystal compound forms a mineral called halite. For 10 points, name this ionic compound symbolized NaCl.
answer: table salt [or sodium chloride; or NaCl; or halite before it is read; do not prompt or accept any other salts such as “epsom salt”] <The above question is for the category Science Chemistry and was written by Paul Lee>
formatted_text: In 2013, Zhang (jong) et al. produced versions of this compound with differing stoichiometric ratios using high-pressure diamond anvil cells. This compound is produced as a side product in addition to ammonia in the Olin–Raschig process for industrial production of hydrazine. This is the lighter of the two compounds commonly used to make sample plates for IR spectroscopy. It is not a phosphate compound, but this is the compound present in highest concentration in a solution commonly used to wash cells prior to dissociation. A solution containing this compound is used to remove any aqueous workup from the organic layer during liquid-liquid extraction. This cubic crystal compound forms a mineral called halite. For 10 points, name this ionic compound symbolized NaCl.
formatted_answer: table salt [or sodium chloride; or NaCl; or halite before it is read; do not prompt or accept any other salts such as “epsom salt”] <The above question is for the category Science Chemistry and was written by Paul Lee>

text: Disagreements over whether or not to undergo this process were the subject of the “suicide paragraph” of the coalitions of Jan Peder Syse (YAHN pair SUE-suh) and Jens Stoltenberg (YENS STOLE-tin-burg). Politicians signed the Snagov Declaration agreeing to undergo this process. Anne Enger Lahnstein lead the “no” side in a referendum which rejected a plan to undergo this process in 1994. The A8 group of states underwent this process simultaneously. In order to undergo this process, countries must meet the Copenhagen Criteria and agree to accept the acquis communautaire (ah-KEE koh-MYOO-noh-TAIR). Austria, Finland and Sweden underwent this process in 1995. For 10 points, undoing what process of joining a continental organization was the primary aim of the 2016 Brexit referendum?
answer: joining the European Union [accept equivalents for “joining” such as acceeding or becoming a member; accept EU or EEC or European Economic Community in place of “European Union”] <The above question is for the category History European 1914-present and was written by Daoud Jackson>
formatted_text: Disagreements over whether or not to undergo this process were the subject of the “suicide paragraph” of the coalitions of Jan Peder Syse (YAHN pair SUE-suh) and Jens Stoltenberg (YENS STOLE-tin-burg). Politicians signed the Snagov Declaration agreeing to undergo this process. Anne Enger Lahnstein lead the “no” side in a referendum which rejected a plan to undergo this process in 1994. The A8 group of states underwent this process simultaneously. In order to undergo this process, countries must meet the Copenhagen Criteria and agree to accept the acquis communautaire (ah-KEE koh-MYOO-noh-TAIR). Austria, Finland and Sweden underwent this process in 1995. For 10 points, undoing what process of joining a continental organization was the primary aim of the 2016 Brexit referendum?
formatted_answer: joining the European Union [accept equivalents for “joining” such as acceeding or becoming a member; accept EU or EEC or European Economic Community in place of “European Union”] <The above question is for the category History European 1914-present and was written by Daoud Jackson>

text: In a poem named after these animals by Patrick Galvin, the narrator’s father remembers “his days / With the Royal Munster Fusiliers” while speaking to these animals. In another poem, “A shudder in the loins” of one of these animals “engenders / The broken wall, the burning roof and tower / And Agamemnon dead.” That poem, a Petrarchan sonnet, describes the “terrified vague fingers” of a woman whose thighs are “caressed / By dark webs.” In a poem that begins “The trees are in their autumn beauty,” the narrator writes that “The nineteenth autumn has come upon me / Since I first made my count” of these animals. That poem is about seeing “nine-and fifty” of them “at Coole.” William Butler Yeats wrote about Leda’s encounter with, for 10 points, what kind of large, white bird?
answer: swans <The above question is for the category Literature British Non-Shakespeare and was written by Shan Kothari>
formatted_text: In a poem named after these animals by Patrick Galvin, the narrator’s father remembers “his days / With the Royal Munster Fusiliers” while speaking to these animals. In another poem, “A shudder in the loins” of one of these animals “engenders / The broken wall, the burning roof and tower / And Agamemnon dead.” That poem, a Petrarchan sonnet, describes the “terrified vague fingers” of a woman whose thighs are “caressed / By dark webs.” In a poem that begins “The trees are in their autumn beauty,” the narrator writes that “The nineteenth autumn has come upon me / Since I first made my count” of these animals. That poem is about seeing “nine-and fifty” of them “at Coole.” William Butler Yeats wrote about Leda’s encounter with, for 10 points, what kind of large, white bird?
formatted_answer: swans <The above question is for the category Literature British Non-Shakespeare and was written by Shan Kothari>

text: A mountain in this region has a large lake in a crater at its peak and is named “Academy of Science.” Indigenous people from this region, including the Itelmens, frequently lamented that the big-raven god Kutkh created such an inhospitable world. A formation of large stones called the “three brothers” appears to guard the mouth of Avacha Bay on the coast of this peninsula. A subspecies of brown bear from this peninsula has subtly violet-tinted fur and is the largest in all of Eurasia. The mountain of Kikhpinych (keek-pin-EECH) stands near the Valley of Geysers in this region, which is home to the Koryak people and has twenty-nine active volcanoes. The Commander Islands lie east of this peninsula, which sits between the Sea of Okhotsk and the Bering Sea. For 10 points, name this far eastern Russian peninsula northeast of Japan.
answer: Kamchatka Peninsula [or Poluostrov Kamchatka; prompt on Russian Far East; prompt on Siberia] <The above question is for the category Geography World and was written by John Marvin>
formatted_text: A mountain in this region has a large lake in a crater at its peak and is named “Academy of Science.” Indigenous people from this region, including the Itelmens, frequently lamented that the big-raven god Kutkh created such an inhospitable world. A formation of large stones called the “three brothers” appears to guard the mouth of Avacha Bay on the coast of this peninsula. A subspecies of brown bear from this peninsula has subtly violet-tinted fur and is the largest in all of Eurasia. The mountain of Kikhpinych (keek-pin-EECH) stands near the Valley of Geysers in this region, which is home to the Koryak people and has twenty-nine active volcanoes. The Commander Islands lie east of this peninsula, which sits between the Sea of Okhotsk and the Bering Sea. For 10 points, name this far eastern Russian peninsula northeast of Japan.
formatted_answer: Kamchatka Peninsula [or Poluostrov Kamchatka; prompt on Russian Far East; prompt on Siberia] <The above question is for the category Geography World and was written by John Marvin>

text: A cuneiform tablet which lists Nebo-Sarsekim as a court eunuch suggests the historicity of a list of Babylonian officials in this Biblical book. This book is the only work of prophecy to contain content which scholars attribute to the Deuteronomist source. A passage in this book referring to a “new covenant” was later re-interpreted by Christians as referring to Christ’s institution at the last supper. This book’s prophet buys a field in Anathoth, breaks a clay jug in front of the priests, and wears an oxen yoke which the false prophet Hananiah breaks. The king Zedekiah throws the prophet of this book into a cistern. For 10 points, name this Old Testament book, one of the major prophets, attributed to the “The Weeping Prophet.”
answer: Jeremiah [or Yirmeyahu; or Irmiyā; or Ieremias] <The above question is for the category RMP Christian/Bible Religion and was written by John Marvin>

The king Zedekiah throws the prophet of this book into a cistern. For 10 points, name this Old Testament book, one of the major prophets, attributed to the “The Weeping Prophet.”
formatted_answer: Jeremiah [or Yirmeyahu; or Irmiyā; or Ieremias] <The above question is for the category RMP Christian/Bible Religion and was written by John Marvin>

text: Jack Michael identified twelve total “operations” that drive this psychological phenomenon. A type of therapy developed by William Miller and Stephen Rollnick is named for this kind of “interviewing.” The namesake “salience” of this phenomenon is composed of incentive and aversive forms. Frederick Herzberg’s two-factor theory couples levels of “hygiene factors” to levels of this psychological phenomenon. Internal “push” factors” and goal-derived “pull” factors combine to create this phenomenon. For 10 points, name this psychological phenomenon of being willing to initiate behavior, which industrial psychologists study with regard to employees.
answer: motivation [or motivating or being motivated or other word forms] <The above question is for the category Social Science Psychology and was written by Penelope Ashe>

formatted_answer: motivation [or motivating or being motivated or other word forms] <The above question is for the category Social Science Psychology and was written by Penelope Ashe>

text: A plant-derived auxin-inducible system triggers this process in targets to produce conditional mutants. An unusual stimulation for a form of this process is the binding of ornithine decarboxylase to its antizyme in response to high polyamine levels. The rate of this process is partly governed by the N-end rule and is enhanced by PEST sequences and other degrons. Cathepsins directly perform this process and are activated by the acidity of the lysosome. This process can occur in a ubiquitin-dependent form via the proteasome. For 10 points, name this process performed by proteases, the catabolism of proteins.
answer: proteolysis [or protein degradation; or any common-language answer involving proteins being broken down; prompt on protein metabolism; prompt on breakdown or breaking down or degradation with “what’s being degraded?”] <The above question is for the category Science Biology and was written by Joelle Smart>

text: This author described meeting a “worthy clerk,” ‘whose rhetoric so sweet” illuminated all of poetry. Some scholars believe this author was present at the wedding of the Duke of Clarence and Violante Visconti, at which he may have met two of his chief influences. This author drew upon an earlier Italian book when writing his Legend of Good Women. This author adapted Boccaccio’s (bo-KAH-cho’s) Teseida to write a story in which Emily’s love is battled for by Palamon and Arcite. This author may have been influenced by Italian humanism while serving in the court of King Edward III, and he imitated one of Petrarch’s sonnets in his poem Troilus and Criseyde. For 10 points, name this author whose continental influences are clear in the Clerk’s and Knight’s Tales, two of his Canterbury Tales.
answer: Geoffrey Chaucer <The above question is for the category Literature British Non-Shakespeare and was written by Joseph Krol> 2018 National All-Star Academic Tournament Round 19 – Bonuses
formatted_text: This author described meeting a “worthy clerk,” ‘whose rhetoric so sweet” illuminated all of poetry. This author adapted Boccaccio’s (bo-KAH-cho’s) Teseida to write a story in which Emily’s love is battled for by Palamon and Arcite. formatted_answer: Geoffrey Chaucer <The above question is for the category Literature British Non-Shakespeare and was written by Joseph Krol> 2018 National All-Star Academic Tournament Round 19 – Bonuses

text: This man designs a trap for the King of the Ravens, who is forced to watch corn grow but ultimately killed by this man’s rival, the inventor of dice games Pau-Puk-Keewis. This character uses a magic canoe that moves without paddles but does get stuck on a sandbar until Kwasind assists. This character is told by a woodpecker that he can fire arrows directly at the top of Pearl-Feather’s head. This conqueror of the fish-god Mishe-Nahma invents reading and writing after he is born to the west wind Mudjekeewis and Wenonah, the daughter of Nokomis, near “Gitchee Gumee” or Lake Superior. For 10 points, name this husband of Minnehaha and protagonist of a “song” by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow.
answer: Hiawatha <The above question is for the category Literature American and was written by Penelope Ashe>
formatted_text: This man designs a trap for the King of the Ravens, who is forced to watch corn grow but ultimately killed by this man’s rival, the inventor of dice games Pau-Puk-Keewis. For 10 points, name this husband of Minnehaha and protagonist of a “song” by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow.
formatted_answer: Hiawatha <The above question is for the category Literature American and was written by Penelope Ashe>

text: This adjective appears in the title of a book which discusses the conflict between “moral-god” and “river-god” in Huckleberry Finn , claims that the Kinsey Report reduced sexuality from a “social” to a “physical fact,” and ends with “The Meaning of a Literary Idea.” George Dangerfield argued that the confluence of four “great rebellions” in the early 1910s led to the “strange death” of this kind of “England,” and Lionel Trilling’s essay collection is titled for this kind of “imagination.” This word describes a political approach based on empathy and incrementalism that needs no philosophical foundation, according to Contingency, Irony, and Solidarity by Richard Rorty. For 10 points, give this term describing political parties committed to “classical” ideals of the Enlightenment such as the governing parties of Australia and Canada.
answer: liberal [or liberalism] <The above question is for the category Social Science Social Criticism and was written by Penelope Ashe>
formatted_text: This adjective appears in the title of a book which discusses the conflict between “moral-god” and “river-god” in Huckleberry Finn , claims that the Kinsey Report reduced sexuality from a “social” to a “physical fact,” and ends with “The Meaning of a Literary Idea.” George Dangerfield argued that the confluence of four “great rebellions” in the early 1910s led to the “strange death” of this kind of “England,” and Lionel Trilling’s essay collection is titled for this kind of “imagination.” This word describes a political approach based on empathy and incrementalism that needs no philosophical foundation, according to Contingency, Irony, and Solidarity by Richard Rorty. formatted_answer: liberal [or liberalism] <The above question is for the category Social Science Social Criticism and was written by Penelope Ashe>

text: A building of this type was designed in three concentric square rings, with the outer ring made of load-bearing red brick and the innermost ring being a central atrium with four large circular holes in its concrete walls, revealing the different floors of the middle ring. Another building of this type features bright red hallways and yellow illuminated escalators to distinguish from its typical blue palette. Louis Kahn designed one of these buildings for Phillips Exeter Academy, and Rem Koolhaas designed an oddly-shaped one with a glass exterior in Seattle. The firm of McKim, Mead and White designed these buildings for the cities of Boston and New York, in the latter case flanking the main entrance with statues of lions. For 10 points, name these structures for housing books.
answer: library [or libraries] <The above question is for the category Arts Architecture and was written by John Marvin>
formatted_text: A building of this type was designed in three concentric square rings, with the outer ring made of load-bearing red brick and the innermost ring being a central atrium with four large circular holes in its concrete walls, revealing the different floors of the middle ring. text: One of these two people charmed the other by using the phrase “we authors” to indicate a common bond. Upon one of these people’s death, the other sent primroses to the funeral, an action that give the Primrose League its name. A law championed by one of these people led the younger one to sign letters using the Latin initials “R&I.” In speaking to Matthew Arnold, one of these people explained his relationship with the other as laying flattery on “with a trowel.” The older of these people introduced the Royal Titles Act to please the younger one. One of these two people had a more fractious relationship with the other’s rival, the leader of the Liberal Party. For 10 points, name these two British leaders, a Conservative prime minister of Jewish descent and his queen.
answer: Benjamin Disraeli AND Queen Victoria [accept Alexandrina Victoria in place of “Victoria”; accept in either order] <The above question is for the category History European 1400-1914 and was written by Mike Cheyne>
formatted_text: One of these two people charmed the other by using the phrase “we authors” to indicate a common bond. formatted_answer: Benjamin Disraeli AND Queen Victoria [accept Alexandrina Victoria in place of “Victoria”; accept in either order] <The above question is for the category History European 1400-1914 and was written by Mike Cheyne>

text: A recent line of research that builds from Per Martin-Löf’s (PAIR martin-LUFF’s) “intuitionistic” theory of these things tries to use them for the “univalent foundations” of mathematics by extending the notion of homotopy to them; that theory of these things has been put forth by Vladimir Voevodsky (voy-eh-VOD-skee). The lambda calculus without these things can be thought of as really being the lambda calculus with only one of these things. One can convert an object from one of these things to another using a double equals sign in Javascript, known as “coercion.” Programming languages that check these things at compile-time or runtime are classified as having “static” or “dynamic” kinds of these things, respectively. For 10 points, name this classification that identifies what kind of data is represented by a value, such as “float,” “real,” or “boolean” (BOO-lee-in).
answer: types [or data types; or type theory; or type system; or typed; or typing] <The above question is for the category Science Computer Science and was written by John Marvin>

formatted_answer: types [or data types; or type theory; or type system; or typed; or typing] <The above question is for the category Science Computer Science and was written by John Marvin>

text: Ovid describes how this hero used a spear to pin a monster to a tree, causing that oak to break under its weight. The account of Apollodorus differs from that of Homer’s in suggesting that Amphion and Zethus enhanced rather than carried out an achievement of this man. Late in his life, this man and his wife were turned into serpents. This man led a group of five “Spartoi” who emerged after he sowed the teeth of a dragon he had killed. At Delphi, this man was told to forget about his abducted sister Europa and follow a bull with the sign of a moon on its flank which he was to follow until it collapsed. A cursed necklace was given to this man’s wife Harmonia at their wedding. For 10 points, identify this founder of Thebes.
answer: Cadmus <The above question is for the category RMP Greek/Roman Myth and was written by Daoud Jackson>
formatted_text: Ovid describes how this hero used a spear to pin a monster to a tree, causing that oak to break under its weight. A cursed necklace was given to this man’s wife Harmonia at their wedding. For 10 points, identify this founder of Thebes.
formatted_answer: Cadmus <The above question is for the category RMP Greek/Roman Myth and was written by Daoud Jackson>

text: A character in this play stews up a concoction to give Diana the dog an abortion. A character in this play reveals he snuck into a garden to stare at the title woman from a pile of weeds. In this play, the title character’s father, The Count, never appears, but his boots are always present. A character in this play yells “kill me too… you who can butcher an innocent bird without a tremble” after her pet canary is beheaded with a butcher’s knife. This play, which its author explained was strongly influenced by Darwinism, ends as the title character is convinced to kill herself with a shaving razor. For 10 points, name this play about the valet Jean’s relationship with the title woman, by August Strindberg.
answer: Miss Julie [or Fröken Julie] <The above question is for the category Literature European and was written by John Marvin>

formatted_answer: Miss Julie [or Fröken Julie] <The above question is for the category Literature European and was written by John Marvin>

text: The corrosion of gyros on this device led to the adoption of pressurized nitrogen instead of oxygen for suspension fluid. One project carried out with this device was entitled CANDELS. A system of mirrors called COSTAR replaced some of this tool’s instruments. Its successor is named after James Webb. This instrument captured its namesake Deep Field, Ultra Deep Field, and Extreme Deep Field. This instrument captured high-resolution images of Shoemaker-Levy 9’s collision with Jupiter. Photographs taken by this device for its first three years in operation were out of focus due to an aberration with a mirror. It is named after the discoverer of galaxies similar to ours. For 10 points, name this space telescope.
answer: Hubble Space Telescope [or HST] <The above question is for the category Science Astronomy and was written by Eric Mukherjee>
formatted_text: The corrosion of gyros on this device led to the adoption of pressurized nitrogen instead of oxygen for suspension fluid.
